questions.text: Which of the following is seen in patients with brain stem injury?
questions.solution:
Patients with brain stem injury develop type 2 respiratory failure. It is characterized by low pO2 and high pCO2.

Acute respiratory failure refers to acute impairment in gas exchange between the lungs and the blood causing hypoxia with or without hypercapnia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man underwent emergency surgery following a road traffic accident. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia. Two days later, he developed features of respiratory failure. Which of the following types is likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
The features of respiratory failure in the perioperative period of this patient is most likely due to lung atelectasis. Type 3 respiratory failure is most likely to be present in him.

Type 3 respiratory failure is also known as perioperative respiratory failure.

After general anesthesia, there is a decrease in functional residual capacity due to a reduction in muscular tone. This leads to airway closure and the collapse of the dependent lung units.

Atelectasis can be treated by frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright positioning, and control of incisional and abdominal pain. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.

questions.text: A patient is admitted for myocardial infarction complicated by severe mitral regurgitation. He suddenly develops shortness of breath, decreased urine output, and drowsiness. Blood pressure is 86/40 mmHg, pulse 120 bpm, and respiratory rate 24 per minute. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Up to 40% of cardiac output may be distributed to the respiratory muscles
Patient will develop type 2 respiratory failure
Intubation and mechanical ventilation are treatment of choice
Batwing appearance can be expected on an x-ray

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cardiogenic shock. He is likely to develop type 4 respiratory failure, not type 2. 

Patients in cardiogenic shock often have respiratory distress secondary to acute pulmonary edema (batwing appearance on x-ray). This increases the requirement of oxygen delivery to the respiratory muscles from <5% to up to 40% of cardiac output.

Hypoperfusion and increased oxygen requirement lead to inadequate perfusion of respiratory muscles which causes type 4 respiratory failure.

Intubation and mechanical ventilation are the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 47-year-old construction site worker is admitted for fever, nausea, vomiting, and pain abdomen radiating to the back. The next day he develops sudden onset breathlessness and hypoxia. He has been drinking daily for the past 10 years. He had a myocardial infarction 6 months back. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray finding is suggestive of ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) secondary to acute pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis gives rise to inflammatory processes and endothelial damage that results in ARDS. 

CXR features in ARDS:

  • Early findings -  normal or diffuse alveolar opacities (consolidation), bilateral and which obscure the pulmonary vascular markings
  • Late findings - these opacities progress to more extensive consolidation that is diffuse

Clinical disorders commonly associated with ARDS:

  • Direct lung injury:
    • Pneumonia
    • Aspiration of gastric contents
    • Pulmonary contusion
    • Near-drowning
    • Toxic inhalation injury
  • Indirect lung injury:
    • Sepsis
    • Severe trauma- multiple fractures, flail chest, head trauma, burns
    • Multiple transfusions
    • Drug overdose
    • Pancreatitis
    • Post-cardiopulmonary bypass

questions.text: According to the berlin definition, moderate ARDS is characterized by all, except
questions.solution:
Moderate ARDS is characterized by PaO2/FiO2: 101 - 200 mmHg. PaO2/FiO2: 200 - 300 mm/Hg is classified as mild ARDS. 

Diagnostic criteria in ARDS—Berlin definition:(requires each of the following criteria to be present to diagnose ARDS)

  • Onset - Acute: Respiratory symptoms must have begun < 1 week of a known clinical insult
  • Bilateral alveolar or interstitial infiltrates: on a chest X-ray image or CT scan
  • Respiratory failure must not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. Objective assessment e.g Echo should be done in cases of no known cause.
  • Impairment of oxygenation: The severity of hypoxemia defines the severity of ARDS.

Severity

PaO2/FiO2

(On ventilator settings that include PEEP ≥5 cm H2O)

Mild

> 200 mmHg but ≤ 300 mmHg

Moderate

 > 100 mmHg but ≤ 200 mmHg
Severe ≤ 100 mmHg

Note: American-European Consensus Conference (AECC) classification of ARDS is no longer used.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be present in patients with ARDS?
questions.solution:
Increased left atrial pressure is not likely to be present in ARDS.

ARDS is characterized by

  • PCWP of ≤18 mmHg with normal LA pressure
  • Decreased pulmonary compliance
  • Increased pulmonary artery pressure
  • Severe hypoxemia

questions.text: A fisherman was rushed to the ED following a near-drowning incident. On arrival, he was unconscious and was not breathing. He was resuscitated and stabilized. A few hours later, he developed sudden onset breathlessness and low saturation. Chest X-ray showed diffuse alveolar opacities. He was started on mechanical ventilation. What will be the recommended ventilator setting for him?

choices.text: Low tidal volume and high PEEP
Low tidal volume and low PEEP
High tidal volume and high PEEP
High tidal volume and low PEEP

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ARDS secondary to drowning. The ventilator setting recommended is low tidal volume and high PEEP.

Drowning causes direct lung injury. The aspiration of water into the lungs damages the surfactant. This disrupts the alveolar-capillary membrane and leads to alveolar edema, resulting in ARDS.

The ventilator settings recommended in ARDS are:

  • Low tidal volume: To avoid barotrauma due to overdistention of the alveoli.
  • High PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure): This prevents the collapse of alveoli at the end of the expiration and improves oxygenation.
